title: What is the Accounting Equation?
description: Understand the fundamental equation that forms the basis of double-entry bookkeeping

words.fact: Assets are resources controlled by a company as a result of past events, from which future economic benefits are expected to flow. Assets include cash, inventory, equipment, buildings, and accounts receivable. They represent what a company owns and can be current (short-term) or non-current (long-term).

Liabilities are present obligations of a company arising from past events, the settlement of which is expected to result in an outflow of resources. Liabilities represent what a company owes to creditors and include accounts payable, loans, bonds, and accrued expenses.

Equity represents the residual interest in the assets of a company after deducting liabilities. Also called shareholders' equity or owner's equity, it includes contributed capital (from issuing shares) and retained earnings (accumulated profits not distributed as dividends).

A debit is an accounting entry that increases asset or expense accounts, or decreases liability, revenue, or equity accounts. In double-entry bookkeeping, debits are recorded on the left side of a ledger account. Every transaction must have at least one debit and one credit.

A credit is an accounting entry that increases liability, revenue, or equity accounts, or decreases asset or expense accounts. Credits are recorded on the right side of a ledger account. The total debits must always equal total credits in every transaction.

The accounting equation must always balance: Assets = Liabilities + Equity. This fundamental principle ensures that every transaction is recorded in a way that maintains this equality. The balance sheet derives its name from this requirement to balance.
